The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger is a thought-provoking and universally appreciated classic that offers viewers an honest portrayal of growing up in a world of uncertainty and individual disconnection. The layers of symbolism present in the novel and the characters represent a wide array of universal themes and make this book one that is easily remembered and reread.

The most striking theme in the book is the importance of Bildungsroman, which essentially means “education through growth”. This journey of growth takes young Holden from a state of confusion and hopelessness to one of clarity and maturity, with symbolic insights like building a bridge and walking across it being essential elements of this process. The protagonist Holden Caulfield, despite his many failures, is able to move from the depths of sorrow and misunderstanding to comprehend its prevailing beauty and opportunity in a warmer and happier world. 

The Catcher in the Rye has won so many awards and bettered so many lives with its themes of growing up and becoming mature, but is also a beloved classic in its own right.
